title: How to Deal with Foot Cramps

steps.title: Stop your activity.
steps.content: Stop your activity. If you are exercising or performing some activity that causes the spasm or cramp to start, then stop doing whatever you were doing that triggered the cramp. [1] X Research source Avoid continuing activities that you recognize as causing added strain on your feet that leads to the pain and cramping. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Stretch the cramped muscle.
steps.content: Stretch the cramped muscle. Muscle cramps are sudden, unexpected, and repeated contractions causing spasms of a muscle. To stop the foot or toe cramp quickly, the cramped muscle needs to be stretched. [3] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source By stretching the muscle, you are preventing it from remaining in the contracted or cramped position. [4] X Research source Stretching a cramped muscle works best if you can hold the stretched position for about a minute or longer, and until the cramp begins to release or until the repeated contractions begin to slow/stop. You may need to repeat the stretched position if you feel the cramp returning. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The arch of the foot and the toes are the most common areas of the foot where cramping occurs. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Stretch your arches by grabbing your toes with your hand while seated, and pull them upward until you feel a stretch in your arch. Hold this position for 30 seconds, and release. If you feel the cramp returning then repeat the stretch. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source You can also try rolling a tennis ball under your foot. While seated or standing, you can use this tool under the pad of the toes, the arch, and the heel.

steps.title: Put weight on the cramping foot.
steps.content: Put weight on the cramping foot. This is a good way to stretch muscles, tendons, and ligaments that are causing the cramping in either your arch or your toe area. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source As quickly as possible when you become aware that your foot or toe area is starting to cramp, change positions so that your body weight is on the painful foot. [9] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Walk around.
steps.content: Walk around. As the pain starts to subside, walk around. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Continue to walk around to prevent the area from cramping again. Once a cramp or spasm occurs, the muscles in the area may continue to cramp or spasm until it is completely relaxed. This means that you may need to remain standing and/or walking around for at least three minutes, or even longer, until you feel the area is relaxed and there is no further pain. [11] X Research source Be prepared to continue walking if the pain comes back when you remove the added pressure provided by your body weight. [12] X Research source Once the pain is better, continue to stretch until you feel the muscles are relaxed. Stretch your arch and your toes by placing a towel on the ground and picking it up by scrunching your toes together. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Add a stretch for your calf muscles to provide additional relief if needed to stretch the muscles, tendons, and ligaments that attach to your heel area. Even if your calf muscle is not cramping, it may prove helpful to stretch your calf muscles once the initial pain is managed. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Place one foot flat on the floor about four to five foot-lengths away from a wall. Lean into the wall with your hands until you feel a stretch in your calf muscles while keeping your foot flat on the floor. Hold for 30 seconds then repeat if you feel the foot or toe cramp returning. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It is beneficial to do this stretch with the knee straight and also with the knee bent. This will stretch both components of the calf muscle.

steps.title: Massage your foot.
steps.content: Massage your foot. In addition to stretching your foot or toes that are cramping, remove your shoes and socks and gently massage the area. [16] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Athletic Trainer Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. Keep your foot and toes in the stretched position as you massage the area. [17] X Research source Massage your foot and locate the hardened muscle that is cramping. Using your thumbs, massage the hardened area of the cramp. You may need to be fairly firm and aggressive over the hardened muscle to create relief. Continue to massage the area until the muscle begins to relax. [18] X Research source Begin to massage the surrounding area, returning to the primary trigger point as you massage. Work in either circular or stretching motions with your hands as your massage the areas. [19] X Research source Pull your toes upward as you massage if they are being drawn down or if your arch is cramping. [20] X Research source Use a downward pull to stretch your toes if they are cramped in a position that is pulling them upward. Continue your massage for two to three minutes, or until you feel the cramped muscle has relaxed and is no longer painful. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Apply heat.
steps.content: Apply heat. If the muscle is currently cramping, heat helps when applied to tightened muscles. [22] X Research source Use a heating pad or crushable hot pack as a heat source to relieve the tension in the muscle. After the cramp subsides, if you have any residual pain from the event, ice applications can help to relieve sore and tender muscles. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Apply ice.
steps.content: Apply ice. Ice your foot regularly for several days to help the area to recover from overuse, an injury, or improper-fitting footwear. [24] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Avoid applying ice directly to the skin. Use a thin towel between your skin and the cold pack or ice source to avoid damaging the skin. [25] X Research source Apply the ice for 15 to 20 minutes several times each day for two to five days, or until the soreness and tenderness subsides. [26] X Research source Apply ice to the bottom of your foot and heel area while standing by gently rolling a frozen 12 to 16 ounce water bottle along the bottom of your foot. Be sure you have support so you do not fall. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Rest your foot.
steps.content: Rest your foot. Foot pain and cramping can be caused by several variables including either an injury or overuse. [28] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your foot is made of a complex arrangement of bones, ligaments, tendons, and muscles. Any of these can be overworked or injured which leads to foot pain, spasms, and cramping. [29] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Foot pain and cramps caused by both injuries and overuse usually respond to rest. [30] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source There is no clear time frame recommended for staying off your foot if the cramping caused by overuse other than watching your pain level and following any instructions provided by your doctor. Take opportunities to rest your feet as often as possible. [31] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This may include a few days away from constant standing or walking, wearing work shoes or boots that may be triggering the cramps, or other activities that keep you on your feet for the majority of the day. [32] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you have suffered a specific injury, stay off your feet for the amount of time directed by your doctor. [33] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Exercise regularly.
steps.content: Exercise regularly. Routine exercise keeps your muscles in good condition. [34] X Research source Gradually increase your intensity of aerobic exercises to help condition the muscles, tendons, and ligaments in your feet and to reduce your experience with cramps. Swimming is a great aerobic exercise to treat problems with foot pain and cramps without bearing weight through the feet and unloading the joints. [35] X Research source Work towards improving your level of fitness. Include stretching and flexibility exercises both before and after you exercise. [36] X Research source If you already exercise regularly, evaluate your workout routines to determine if any existing exercises are contributing to your cramps.

steps.title: Wear shoes that are supportive.
steps.content: Wear shoes that are supportive. Select shoes that fit well all around, have shanks and solid heel counters built in, and provide good support. A shank is a supportive strip that runs along the bottom of the shoe. It is not visible, so it is difficult to tell if the shoe manufacturer included a shank in the design. If the shoe is flimsy, and easy to bend in the middle, then it probably does not have a shank. [37] X Research source The heel counter is also not visible, but the presence of a solid heel counter can be determined by pressing inward on the middle, upper area of the back part of the shoe. If it easily collapses to the inside, then the heel counter is not very strong. The more rigid and supportive the heel counter is, the more difficult it will be to push the upper back part of the shoe toward the inside sole. [38] X Research source Many shoe stores have specialists who can evaluate your gait and fit you properly.

steps.title: Replace shoes with worn soles.
steps.content: Replace shoes with worn soles. Prevent heel pain and plantar fasciitis by discarding shoes with worn soles and heels. Worn soles and heels contribute to an uneven step with heel counters that have lost some of their support. Discard old shoes and replace with new ones that have the proper support. Be aware that wearing high-heeled shoes may be part of the cause of repeated foot and toe cramps.

steps.title: Keep your feet and toes flexible.
steps.content: Keep your feet and toes flexible. Routinely performing flexibility exercises can work to prevent foot and toe cramps. Improve the flexibility and strength in your toes by raising your foot into a stretched position as if you were standing on your tip toes. Hold for five seconds and repeat ten times. Switch to the other foot. Try holding onto a wall or other support and raising yourself onto your toes, like a ballet dancer. Hold for five seconds and repeat ten times, then switch to the other foot. From a seated position, lift your flat foot onto your toes, but this time curl your toes inward. Hold for five seconds, repeat ten times, then switch to the other foot. Roll a golf ball along the bottom of your foot for two minutes, then switch to the other foot. Place several marbles, as many as 20, on the floor then pick them up one by one with your toes and place them into a bowl or other container. Switch feet and repeat the exercise.

steps.title: Walk barefoot in the sand.
steps.content: Walk barefoot in the sand. While some foot conditions recommend avoiding walking barefoot, foot and toe cramps benefit from the foot conditioning this provides. Walking barefoot in the sand helps to strengthen your toes along with all the small intrinsic muscles of the foot and ankle and provides a gentle massage for your feet.

steps.title: Stay hydrated.
steps.content: Stay hydrated. Dehydration is a common cause of foot and toe cramps. [39] X Expert Source Francisco Gomez Athletic Trainer Expert Interview. 24 October 2019. Drink water before and after you exercise, and throughout the day to be sure you are getting enough fluids. Try drinking an electrolyte-enhanced sports drink or water; very often it is an electrolyte imbalance causing cramps. You may also want to keep a glass of water at your bedside for cramps that may occur during the night.

steps.title: Eat a balanced diet.
steps.content: Eat a balanced diet. Nutrition is an important part of giving your body and your muscles what they need to function properly and reduce problems like cramping. Muscles use potassium, calcium, and magnesium. Include foods like bananas, dairy products, fresh vegetables, beans, and nuts.

steps.title: Seek immediate attention if necessary.
steps.content: Seek immediate attention if necessary. If you develop severe pain or swelling, see a doctor promptly. [40] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Also seek medical attention quickly if you are unable to walk or put weight on your foot. [41] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If there are areas of broken skin that are oozing, or if you have any signs of infection, seek immediate medical attention. [42] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Signs of infection include redness, warmth or tenderness to the touch, or a fever of 100 °F (37.7 °C) or higher. [43] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Also seek immediate care if you have any persistent pain or cramping and you have diabetes. [44] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Pay attention to any related symptoms.
steps.content: Pay attention to any related symptoms. If you notice any changes in the immediate area, or if both feet become painful or are cramping, make an appointment to have your feet examined. [45] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Watch for symptoms such as redness, swelling, a burning sensation, numbness , tingling, or tenderness to the touch. See your doctor if any of these symptoms develop. [46] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: See your doctor with persistent cramps.
steps.content: See your doctor with persistent cramps. Cramping and pain that continues for more than one week, with or without using rest and ice applications, warrants medical evaluation. [47] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Persistent cramps in one or both feet may indicate an underlying condition with your feet or possibly even a medical cause for the problem.

steps.title: Consider an underlying medical condition.
steps.content: Consider an underlying medical condition. Work with your doctor to evaluate for possible medical causes of your foot cramps if they persist. Some medical conditions that may be causing your foot pain and cramps include the following: [48] X Research source Abnormal levels of electrolytes in the body. [49] X Research source Dehydration caused by a need to increase your intake of water and/or electrolytes. [50] X Research source Thyroid disorders. [51] X Research source Vitamin D deficiency. [52] X Research source Kidney disease including early stages as well as more severe forms of kidney disease that require dialysis. [53] X Research source Diabetes, both type 1 and type 2. [54] X Research source Peripheral arterial disease. [55] X Research source Arthritis, both rheumatoid and osteoarthritis. [56] X Research source Gout, which usually does not cause direct cramps but does cause severe and intense pain. [57] X Research source Cold stress or trench foot, which is caused by working in conditions where your feet stay either exposed to cold or exposed to warmer temperatures, as high as in the 60’s °F, but stay consistently wet. [58] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Nerve damage to either a single nerve or to a bundle of nerve fibers. [59] X Research source Brain disorders such as Parkinson’s, multiple sclerosis, Huntington’s disease, and muscle dystonias. [60] X Research source Pregnancy, most often with foot cramping and pain in the third trimester, but can occur anytime during the pregnancy. [61] X Research source

steps.title: Follow any recommendations made by your doctor.
steps.content: Follow any recommendations made by your doctor. Several of the medical conditions listed can be easily resolved. [62] X Research source For example, adjusting your fluid intake and/or the types of beverages you drink may be a simple step that resolves the problem. Use vitamin D supplements if instructed to do so by your doctor. [63] X Research source Follow the directions provided by your doctor to correct the problem. Those instructions may include a needed follow-up with additional recommended tests, adjustments to your medications, or a referral to a specialist. [64] X Research source

steps.title: Review your medications.
steps.content: Review your medications. Your doctor may be able to adjust some of your prescribed medications that may be contributing to your cramps. Some examples of medications that may contribute to foot and toe cramps include furosemide, donepezil, neostigmine, raloxifene, tolcapone, albuterol, and lovastatin. This is only a list with examples. If you feel you are taking a different medication that is related to your cramps, discuss this with your doctor. Never adjust your medications on your own. With the help of your doctor, doses can possibly be adjusted to correct the problem or a different medication can be prescribed to replace one that may be contributing to your cramps.
